cdata.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 169, Number 201 (Wednesday, December 6, 2023)][House]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. MOYLAN:H.R. 6638.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Pursuant to Article one of the United States ConstitutionCongress has the power to enact this legislation.The single subject of this legislation is:To increase the number of applicants from Guam to militaryservice academys[Page H6209]

item.text: Referred to the House Committee on Armed Services.

cdata.text:
Guam Service Academy Equality Act

This bill increases from four to five the number of cadets the Delegate in Congress from Guam is authorized to nominate to the U.S. Military Academy, U.S. Naval Academy, and the U.S. Air Force Academy.

bill.title: To amend title 10, United States Code, adjust the number of cadets to be nominated to the United States Military Academy, United States Naval Academy, and United States Airforce Academy and for other purposes.

item.title: To amend title 10, United States Code, adjust the number of cadets to be nominated to the United States Military Academy, United States Naval Academy, and United States Airforce Academy and for other purposes.

To amend title 10, United States Code, adjust the number of cadets to be nominated to the United States Military Academy, United States Naval Academy, and United States Airforce Academy and for other purposes.

latestAction.text: Referred to the House Committee on Armed Services.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
